children.name: make a1
children.definition: make/meɪk/  to produce sth which did not exist before:
examples: ▪ diane makes all her own clothes.
▪ the furniture was made by a swedish firm.
▪ they’ve just finished making a movie about life during the civil war.
▪ my camera was made in taiwan.
make somebody something
▪ i’ll make you a coffee, shall i?
be made of somethingto be made using a particular substance
▪ a bag made of leather
be made from something
to be made by putting together different materials, substances, or parts
▪ people were living in huts made from mud, stones, and straw.
make something out of/from something
▪ you could make some cushion covers out of those curtains.

children.name: create b1
children.definition: create to invent something new and original in art, music, fashion etc: sáng tạo ra, tạo ra
examples: ▪ picasso created a completely new style of painting.
▪ she wanted to create a garden to complement her beautiful home.
▪ this dish was created by master chef marco pierre white

children.name: fashion x
children.definition: fashion/ˈfæʃən/  formal to make something using your hands or simple tools:
examples: ▪ two million years ago our ancestors began to fashion stone tools.
fashion something from something
▪ the man had fashioned a turban from a strip of torn cloth.

children.name: made by a person, not a machine
handmade x
children.definition: handmade use this about furniture, clothes etc that are made by skilled workers, not by machines in a factory: làm bằng tay
examples: all our goods are handmade, and we use only natural materials.
a beautiful handmade rug

children.name: homemade x
children.definition: homemade use this about food and drinks that are made at home, not in a factory: nhà làm
examples: try one of these homemade cookies. they’re delicious.
a bowl of homemade soup

children.name: to make sth quickly using whatever materials you have
knock off x
children.definition: knock off/knock upinformal /ˌnɒk ˈɒf, ˌnɒk ˈʌpǁˌnɑːk-/  to make something quickly and without using much effort:
examples: knock off/up something
▪ she was always good on the sewing machine. she could knock off an outfit in two hours.
knock somebody up something british
▪ i could knock you up a couple of poached eggs.

children.name: throw together x
children.definition: throw together/ˈθrəʊ təˌgeðəʳ/  to make something quickly and not very carefully, especially because you are in a hurry:
examples: throw together something
▪ sheryl had thrown together his costume somewhat haphazardly.
throw something together
▪ we had 15 minutes to throw lunch together, eat, and get changed.

children.name: rig up x
children.definition: rig up/ˌrɪg ˈʌp/  to quickly make something such as a piece of equipment that you only need for a short time, using various materials that you have available:
examples: rig up something
▪ you don’t have blinds or curtains so you’ll need to rig up something to shut out the sunlight.
rig something up
▪ can you rig a gate up to stop the dog getting into my room?
▪ there’s a shower rigged up at the back of the cabin.

children.name: cobble together x
children.definition: cobble together/ˌkɒbəl təˈgeðəʳǁˌkɑː-/  to quickly and roughly make something by hand, using a few simple materials:
examples: cobble together something
▪ she cobbled together a tent from a few pieces of string and a sheet.
cobble something together into something
▪ we were always searching for bits of junk we could cobble together into something artistic.

children.name: run up x
children.definition: run up/ˌrʌn ˈʌp/  british to quickly make a piece of clothing or some curtains, especially using a sewing machine:
examples: ▪ there’s a woman at the end of our street who will run up some curtains for me.
▪ ‘i like your dress.’ ‘oh, thank you. it’s just something i ran up last night.’

children.name: improvise x
children.definition: improvise/ˈɪmprəvaɪz/  to make something using whatever you have available, when you do not have the correct materials: chế
examples: ▪ they had improvised an alarm, using string and empty cans.
improvise something out of something
▪ i improvised a sling for his arm out of a strip of cloth.
improvised[adjective only before noun]
▪ he was standing on an improvised stage.
▪ an improvised shelter

children.name: makeshift x
children.definition: makeshift/ˈmeɪkʃɪft/  made using any materials or objects that are available at the time in order to be used only for a short time: dùng tạm
examples: ▪ using an old tree-trunk as a makeshift table, we ate our picnic.
▪ when we reached the river we found that the makeshift bridge had been swept away.
▪ they rigged up the canvas boat-cover as a makeshift sail.

children.name: when a natural process makes sth
generate b2
children.definition: generategenerateelectricity/heat/powerto produce a lot of electricity, heat etc: tạo ra, phát ra, sinh ra
examples: the friction between the satellite and the atmosphere generates great heat.
france generates a large part of its electricity from nuclear power.

children.name: form b2
children.definition: form if a natural process or chemical reaction forms sth, it makes it, especially over a period of time: tạo ra
examples: hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water.
coal is formed naturally from decomposed organic matter.

children.name: produce b1
children.definition: produce if a natural process or part of your body produces a substance, it makes it, usually for a particular purpose: sản sinh ra
examples: the stomach produces acids which help to digest food.
carbon dioxide is produced during respiration.

children.name: create b1
children.definition: create if a natural process creates sth, it makes sth that was not there before: tạo ra
examples: land movement created the alps.
a bullet exceeding the speed of sound creates two shock waves.
we found that this chemical process created hydrogen chloride as a by-product.

children.name: the creation of sth b2
children.definition: the creation of sth when sth such as a new system, organization, or way of doing sth is started:
examples: the report proposed the creation of an independent scottish parliament.
the creation of an information system for senior managers.

children.name: do a2
children.definition: doverbdid,donemake làm
examples: [ t ] to make, produce or create something
_i can't come out tonight - i've got to do my history essay.
_[ + two objects ]can you do me 20 photocopies of this report/do 20 photocopies of this reportforme?

children.name: give b1
children.definition: giveverbgave,givencause làm cho
examples: [ t ] to produce or cause something
_[ + two objects ]the fresh air gave us an appetite (= made us hungry) .
_what you said has given me an idea.
_the alarm gave(out)a high-pitched sound.

children.name: out of b1
children.definition: out ofprepositionmade from làm từ
examples: (alsoof)used to show what something is made from
_the dress was made out of velvet.

children.name: form b2
children.definition: formverb định hình
examples: [ i or t ] to begin to exist or to make something begin to exist
_a crowd formed around the accident.
_a solution began to form in her mind.
_she formed the clayintoa small bowl.
_i formedthe impression(= the way she behaved suggested to me) that she didn't really want to come.

children.name: generate b2
children.definition: generateverbcreate tạo ra
examples: to cause something to exist
_her latest film has generated a lot ofinterest/excitement.
_the new development will generate 1500 new jobs.
_these measures will increase the club's ability to generaterevenue/income.

children.name: raise b2
children.definition: raiseverbexist dựng, làm ra
examples: to cause to exist
_her answers raiseddoubts/fears/suspicionsin my mind.
_this discussion has raised many importantissues/problems.
_the announcement raised acheer/laugh.
_i want to raise (= talk about) two problems/questionswithyou.
_i want to start my own business if i can raise (= obtain) themoney/cash/capital/funds.
_formalthe chapel was raised (= built) as a memorial to her son.

children.name: recreate c1
children.definition: recreateverb tạo lại
examples: to make something exist or happen again
_they plan to recreate a typical english village injapan.
_their work involves restoring and recreating wildlife habitats all across the country.

children.name: formation c2
children.definition: formationnoun sự hình thành
examples: [ c ] the way something is naturally made or the way it has been arranged
_a rock formation
_cloud formations

children.name: formation c2
children.definition: formationnoun sự hình thành
examples: [ u ] the development of something into a particular thing or shape
_the formation of a crystal

children.name: build a2
children.definition: build/bɪld/  to make something complicated, especially a building, machine, or vehicle, by putting parts together:
examples: ▪ one of jim’s hobbies is building model airplanes.
▪ john and his father built the cabin themselves.
build sth by handbuild something without using machines
▪ every single car is built by hand at the company’s headquarters near turin.

children.name: construct b2
children.definition: construct/kənˈstrʌkt/  to make something, especially something large, solid, and strong, by putting parts together:
examples: ▪ it is easy to construct a wooden framework for plants to grow against.
▪ developers want to construct a replica of the 19th century steam yacht.
construct something from something
▪ the roof frames were constructed from thick, heavy timbers.
